intro: Blepharipappus fremontii, commonly known as the fremont's ghostflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the sunflower family (Asteraceae) and is characterized by its delicate, showy yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and linear, and the plant produces small, wind-dispersed seeds. It is considered a rare and endangered species due to habitat loss and limited distribution.
